snippet: Athens will repeatedly run an obstacle course to pay billions of euros in debts to creditors and to meet basic obligations like salaries and pensions.
abstract: Greece's narrowly-managed payment of 750 million euros to the International Monetary Fund represents only small portion of its obligations as it seeks to repay tens of billions to creditors and maintain basic obligations like salaries and pensions; economists say juggling act is unsustainable as nation's economy takes turn for the worse, and that risk will only increase until foreign creditors agree to forgive some of its 324 million euro debt.

byline.contributor: Niki Kitsantonis contributed reporting from Athens and Jack Ewing from Frankfurt.

lead_paragraph: Athens will repeatedly run an obstacle course to pay billions of euros in debts to creditors and to meet basic obligations like salaries and pensions.

headline.main: Facing Vicious Debt Cycle, Greece Sprints to Apply Fixes
headline.print_headline: Greece, Facing Long-Term Debt Trouble, Sprints to Apply Short-Term Patches
